w:r.w:t: TITLE: Wild Animal and their Homes

The teacher will teach wild animal names and homes by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: rainforest, it is hot, it is cold, sloth, macaw, anteater, arctic, arctic fox, penguin, polar bear, desert, viper, camel, lizard, grassland, zebra, lion, giraffe, skins, prints, wild animals, pets
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for wild animals
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: rainforest, arctic, grassland, desert
This slide will always be the Naativ-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about wild animals!”
Circle the world and talk about the animals that live around the world. See what animals the child knows.
Say what color you see in the rainforest
Circle the picture of the rainforest and say
It is hot in the rainforest.
Ask, “What color do you see in the rainforest? Encourage the child to answer in a complete sentence,
In the rainforest I see a sloth/anteater/macaw
Circle the sloth and briefly see what the child knows about the sloth. See if the child knows a sloth moves slow. Repeat chatting about the next two animals.
Underline the bold sentence beginning and say,
In the rainforest I see a sloth/anteater/ macaw.
Draw where the macaw, sloth and anteater might live in or near this tree.
Circle the tree and briefly explain that these animals live around or in this tree. Ask the child to draw a line where the animal might live in the tree. Do the first one if the child is confused.
Say what color you see in the arcti
Circle the picture of the arctic and say
Circle the snow and ice. Have the child say,
It is cold in the arctic.
Ask, “What color do you see in the arctic? Encourage the child to answer in a complete sentence,
In the arctic I see a penguin/polar bear/arctic fox
Circle the penguin and briefly see what the child knows about the penguin. See if the child knows how a penguin moves. Waddle a bit to show how they move. Repeat chatting about the next two animals.
Underline the bold sentence beginning and say,
In the arctic I see a penguin/polar bear/arctic fox.
I see an arctic fox/polar bear
Circle the pictures. Ask the student what color they see. Ask the student, “What animal do you see?”
It is hot in the desert
Say what color you see in the desert
Circle the picture of the desert and say
Circle the sand. Have the child say,
It is hot in the desert.
Ask, “What color do you see in the desert? Encourage the child to answer in a complete sentence,
In the desert I see a camel/viper/lizard.
Tell what color you see most in the desert
Circle the camel and briefly see what the child knows about the camel. See if the child knows why a camel has a hump on his back. Repeat chatting about the next two animals.
Underline the bold sentence beginning and say,
In the desert I see a camel/viper/lizard.
Ask, “What color do you see the most in the desert?” Encourage the child to answer in a complete phrase, “I see brown in the desert.”
Circle the first picture. Ask, “What animal left this track?” Encourage the child to answer,
Circle the second picture. Ask, “What animal left his track? Encourage the child to answer,
Ask the child where these animals live. Encourage the child to answer in a complete sentence,
A viper lives in the desert, A camel lives in the desert.
Say what color you see in the grassland
Circle the picture of the grassland and say
Circle the grass. Have the child say,
Ask, “What color do you see in the grassland? Encourage the child to answer in a complete sentence,
On the grassland, I see a giraffe/lion/zebra.
Tell what color you see most in the grassland
Circle the giraffe and briefly see what the child knows about the giraffe. See if the child can tell you something unique about the giraffe. Repeat chatting about the next two animals.
Underline the bold sentence beginning and say,
On the grassland, I see a giraffe/lion/zebra.
Ask, “What color do you see the most in the grassland” Encourage the child to answer in a complete phrase, “I see brown on the grassland”
With the help of your teacher, compare and contrast a zebra and a giraffe.

Walk the student through the parts of a Venn Diagram. Explain that the left side will be facts we can say about giraffes. Explain that the right side will be for facts we can say about zebras. Where the circle cross, this is where we can write facts about both animals.

Circle a giraffe’s spot. Ask the child if they know what it is called. If they don’t, tell them they are called spots. Circle the stripes on a giraffe. Ask if the zebra has the same. The child should say no. Explain that a zebra has stripes.
Next encourage the child to tell you something that is the same about both animals. Ask, “Are they both people? Are they both dogs? Are they both animals?” Encourage the child to say,
Then write animals in the middle circle.
If the child is advanced, add more details to the Venn diagram.
Explain that these animals get their own food. Do an action for eating or show some food to make sure students understand.
Circle the picture of the pets and say,
Explain that you have to GIVE food to these animals.
Visual cue: Show pictures of people feeding their pets. Circle the second picture to reinforce the term,
Say the name of the wild animal that this skin belongs to

Circle one skin at a time. See if the child can remember the name of the wild animal the skin belongs to. Prompt the child as necessary. If needed, write the four choices (polar bear, zebra, sloth, giraffe) on the screen.
Match the animal name to the picture.
Ask the child to draw a line from the picture of the animal to the name.
Circle the wild animals you learned about and name them.
Model circling one of the animals and say the name. Encourage the child to circle animals that they know or learned about in this lesson.
